Award.AwardTitle: Theory of Nonlinear Elliptic Equations and Systems
Award.AbstractNarration: Partial differential equations arise naturally in physics, engineering, geometry, and many other fields, and they form the basis for modeling many phenomena in the physical world. The particular class of fully nonlinear elliptic equations and systems is especially important from this perspective. For instance, such equations and systems play a role in the theoretical study of composite materials. This project will contribute to a basic understanding of fully nonlinear elliptic equations and systems, thereby providing scientists and engineers with sharpened insight into various physical processes and ultimately enhancing the quality of consumer products manufactured from composites. As part of the project, the principal investigator will train Ph.D. students, many of whom are expected to continue their careers as educators and help convey the long-term value of mathematical research not only to science and engineering but also, in the end, to society.<br/> <br/>At a technical level, this project is a natural continuation of the principal investigator's earlier work, which includes valuable contributions to this research area. One part of the project concerns a longstanding open problem on the existence and compactness of solutions to a fully nonlinear Yamabe problem. This is equivalent to solving, on a Riemannian manifold, a fully nonlinear elliptic, but not uniformly elliptic, partial differential equation of second order. The current understanding of this type of equations is insufficient, especially compared to what is known for fully nonlinear uniformly elliptic second order equations, where theories are much more mature. The study of this open problem should lead to a better understanding of these elliptic, but not uniformly elliptic, equations. It will also lead to a better understanding of degenerate elliptic fully nonlinear equations of second order. This project will provide new analytical tools for the study of these and other important nonlinear partial differential equations arising from geometry and physics.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partial differential equations (PDEs) are a ubiquitous mathematical framework that naturally arises in physics, engineering, geometry, and a plethora of other scientific and engineering disciplines. They serve as a foundational tool for modeling and understanding a wide array of phenomena in the physical world. In this vast landscape of PDEs, the class of "nonlinear elliptic equations and systems" stands out for its critical importance in comprehending complex systems and processes.

The principal investigator (PI) has made substantial and far-reaching contributions in advancing the understanding of nonlinear elliptic equations and systems. This research has had a profound impact, providing scientists and engineers with invaluable insights into various physical processes. The insights gained from this work may resulted in applications in enhancing the quality of consumer products, thereby benefiting society at large.

Moreover, the PI has played a pivotal role in mentoring and guiding Ph.D. students, many of whom are poised to pursue careers as educators and researchers. The influence of the PI's mentorship extends beyond their direct students; these students, in turn, will impart their mathematical knowledge and instill the long-term value of mathematical research. This cycle ensures that the impact of the PI's contributions extends well into the future, enriching the scientific community and society as a whole.

Delving into the technical aspects of the research, the PI's contributions to the proposed work are noteworthy and highly impactful. One of the significant contributions addresses a longstanding open problem concerning the existence and compactness of solutions to a fully nonlinear Yamabe problem. Collaborating with a fellow researcher, the PI introduced Green's function to the nonlinear Yamabe problem, a fundamental concept with far-reaching implications. This introduction led to the demonstration of the existence and uniqueness of the Green's function, representing a significant advance in this specialized field of study.

Furthermore, in collaboration with colleagues and students, the PI obtained optimal estimates on strain tensors in an insulated conductivity problem. This achievement settled a previously outstanding open problem, showcasing the depth of the PI's expertise and the transformative impact of their work. The settlement of this open problem represents a significant advancement in the field, opening up new avenues of research and practical applications.

In summary, the principal investigator's expertise and contributions in the realm of nonlinear elliptic equations and systems are influential. Their work not only advances the theoretical understanding of mathematical principles but also translates into tangible benefits for society. The PI's dedication to mentorship further solidifies the enduring impact of their work, ensuring the continued growth and development of the mathematical and scientific community.
